questions.question: What is the primary function of an operating system?
questions.option2: To manage computer hardware and software resources

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a type of system call?
questions.option2: File management

questions.question: In a layered operating system structure, which layer is closest to the hardware?
questions.option2: Application layer

questions.question: What is a process in an operating system?
questions.option2: A program in execution

questions.question: Which process state indicates that a process is waiting for some event to occur?
questions.option2: Running

questions.question: What is the main advantage of using threads over processes?
questions.option2: Lower overhead for creation and context switching

questions.question: In which multithreading model are user threads mapped to kernel threads on a one-to-one basis?
questions.option2: One-to-One model

questions.question: What is a critical section in process synchronization?
questions.option1: A section of code that cannot be executed
questions.option2: A section of code where shared resources are accessed
questions.option3: A section of code that handles interrupts
questions.option4: A section of code for error handling

questions.question: Which synchronization mechanism uses wait() and signal() operations?
questions.option2: Semaphore

questions.question: What is the primary goal of CPU scheduling?
questions.option2: To maximize CPU utilization and system throughput

questions.question: Which CPU scheduling algorithm gives the shortest job the highest priority?
questions.option2: Round Robin

questions.question: What is a deadlock in operating systems?
questions.option2: A situation where processes are blocked forever, waiting for each other
questions.option3: A process that uses too much memory
questions.option4: A process that cannot access the CPU

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a necessary condition for deadlock?
questions.option2: Hold and wait

questions.question: What is the Banker's Algorithm used for?
questions.option2: Deadlock avoidance

questions.question: What is swapping in memory management?
questions.option1: Exchanging data between cache and main memory
questions.option2: Moving entire processes between main memory and secondary storage
questions.option4: Moving data between different memory locations

questions.question: In paging, what is a page fault?
questions.option1: An error in the page table
questions.option2: A request for a page that is not currently in main memory

questions.question: Which memory allocation technique divides physical memory into fixed-size blocks?
questions.option2: Paging

questions.question: What is the main advantage of virtual memory?
questions.option2: Ability to run programs larger than physical memory

questions.question: Which page replacement algorithm replaces the page that will not be used for the longest time?
questions.option2: LRU (Least Recently Used)

questions.question: What is the purpose of the Translation Lookaside Buffer (TLB)?
questions.option2: To cache page table entries for faster address translation

questions.question: Which disk scheduling algorithm moves the disk arm in one direction until the end, then reverses?
questions.option2: SSTF (Shortest Seek Time First)

questions.question: What does RAID stand for?
questions.option2: Redundant Array of Independent Disks

questions.question: Which RAID level provides disk striping without parity or mirroring?
questions.option2: RAID 1

questions.question: What is an inode in a file system?
questions.option2: A data structure containing file metadata

questions.question: Which file allocation method stores file blocks in a linked list?
questions.option2: Linked allocation

questions.question: What is the main advantage of indexed file allocation?
questions.option2: Fast sequential access

questions.question: What is DMA (Direct Memory Access) used for?
questions.option2: Memory management
questions.option3: Direct data transfer between I/O devices and memory without CPU intervention

questions.question: Which I/O method allows the CPU to continue with other tasks while I/O operations are in progress?
questions.option2: Programmed I/O

questions.question: What is an access control list (ACL)?
questions.option1: A list of all system users
questions.option2: A list of permissions associated with a resource

questions.question: What is the principle of least privilege in security?
questions.option2: Users should have only the minimum privileges necessary to perform their tasks
questions.option3: All users should have equal privileges

questions.question: Which type of malware replicates itself and spreads to other systems?
questions.option2: Worm

questions.question: What is the purpose of a system call interface?
questions.option2: To provide a standardized way for applications to request OS services

questions.question: In process scheduling, what does the term 'starvation' refer to?
questions.option1: A process using too much memory
questions.option2: A process that never gets CPU time

questions.question: What is the difference between preemptive and non-preemptive scheduling?
questions.option1: Preemptive scheduling allows processes to be interrupted
questions.option2: Non-preemptive scheduling is faster

questions.question: What is internal fragmentation in memory management?
questions.option1: Unused space within allocated memory blocks
questions.option2: Unused space between allocated memory blocks

questions.question: Which memory management technique allows a program to be divided into logical segments?
questions.option2: Segmentation

questions.question: What is thrashing in virtual memory systems?
questions.option2: Excessive paging activity leading to poor performance

questions.question: Which disk scheduling algorithm is also known as elevator algorithm?
questions.option2: SSTF

questions.question: What is a buffer in I/O systems?
questions.option2: A temporary storage area for data being transferred

questions.question: What is the main purpose of spooling in operating systems?
questions.option2: Process scheduling
questions.option3: Managing slow I/O devices by using disk storage as buffer

questions.question: Which file system structure uses a tree-like hierarchy?
questions.option2: Two-level directory

questions.question: What is a race condition in concurrent programming?
questions.option2: Multiple processes competing for CPU time
questions.option3: The outcome depends on the timing of uncontrolled events
questions.option4: A process running at maximum speed

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a monitor in process synchronization?
questions.option2: To provide a high-level synchronization construct

questions.question: In deadlock prevention, what does 'no hold and wait' condition mean?
questions.option2: Processes must request all resources at once

questions.question: What is the working set model in memory management?
questions.option1: A set of processes currently running
questions.option2: A set of pages referenced by a process in a time window
questions.option3: A set of available memory blocks

questions.question: Which encryption method uses the same key for both encryption and decryption?
questions.option2: Public key encryption

questions.question: What is a context switch in operating systems?
questions.option1: Switching between user and kernel mode
questions.option2: Saving and loading process state when switching between processes

questions.question: What is the purpose of the ready queue in process scheduling?
questions.option2: To store processes waiting for I/O
questions.option3: To store processes ready to execute

questions.question: What is demand paging in virtual memory?
questions.option1: Loading all pages at program start
questions.option2: Loading pages only when they are referenced

questions.question: What is the main difference between hard links and soft links in file systems?
questions.option1: Hard links are faster than soft links
questions.option2: Hard links point to the file's inode, soft links point to the file's path
questions.option3: Soft links are more secure than hard links
questions.option4: Hard links use more storage than soft links

questions.question: Which component of the OS is responsible for loading and executing programs?
questions.option2: Process Manager

questions.question: What is the purpose of a dispatcher in CPU scheduling?
questions.option1: To decide which process to run next
questions.option2: To perform context switching

questions.question: Which type of operating system is designed to handle real-time applications with strict deadlines?
questions.option2: Time-sharing OS

questions.question: What is mutual exclusion in process synchronization?
questions.option1: Allowing multiple processes to access a shared resource simultaneously
questions.option2: Ensuring only one process can access a shared resource at a time
questions.option3: Preventing processes from accessing any resources
questions.option4: Allowing processes to share their memory space

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a non-preemptive scheduling algorithm?
questions.option2: Shortest Remaining Time First (SRTF)

questions.question: What is external fragmentation?
questions.option1: Unused space within a memory block
questions.option2: Total memory space existing in small, non-contiguous blocks
questions.option4: Memory that is currently swapped out

questions.question: What is the role of a page table in a paging system?
questions.option2: To map virtual addresses to physical addresses
questions.option4: To keep track of available memory

questions.question: Which of the following is a disadvantage of contiguous memory allocation?
questions.option2: Internal fragmentation

questions.question: What is the least recently used (LRU) page replacement algorithm based on?
questions.option1: The page that has been in memory the longest
questions.option2: The page that will not be used for the longest time
questions.option3: The page that has not been used for the longest period of time
questions.option4: The page with the lowest frequency of use

questions.question: What is the purpose of a boot block in a file system?
questions.option2: To contain the bootstrap program used to load the operating system

questions.question: Which of the following is a characteristic of a distributed operating system?
questions.option2: Multiple autonomous computers working together
questions.option4: Reliance on a single shared memory

questions.question: What is the primary function of a device driver?
questions.option2: To provide an interface between the OS and hardware devices

questions.question: What is polling in the context of I/O operations?
questions.option1: A method for interrupting the CPU
questions.option2: The CPU repeatedly checks the status of an I/O device
questions.option3: A technique for direct memory access
questions.option4: A way to buffer I/O requests

questions.question: Which type of security attack involves intercepting communication between two parties?
questions.option2: Man-in-the-Middle (MitM)

questions.question: What is a system daemon?
questions.option2: A background process that performs system tasks

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the concept of 'multiprogramming'?
questions.option1: Running multiple programs on multiple CPUs simultaneously
questions.option2: Running multiple programs on a single CPU by rapidly switching between them
questions.option3: Running a single program that uses multiple threads
questions.option4: Executing programs in a batch, one after another

questions.question: What is the purpose of a swap space (or paging file) on a disk?
questions.option2: To extend main memory by using disk space

questions.question: What is a 'fork' system call primarily used for?
questions.option2: Creating a new process (child process)

questions.question: In the context of files, what is a 'directory'?
questions.option2: A collection of files and other directories
questions.option3: A hardware component for storing files

questions.question: What is the primary role of a shell in an operating system?
questions.option2: To provide a command-line interface or graphical user interface for user interaction

questions.question: Which type of OS is typically found in embedded systems?
questions.option2: Real-time OS

questions.question: What is the 'producer-consumer problem' a classic example of in OS?
questions.option2: Deadlock

questions.question: Which scheduling algorithm aims to minimize the average waiting time?
questions.option2: Round Robin

questions.question: What is a 'safe state' in deadlock avoidance?
questions.option1: A state where no process is running
questions.option2: A state where the system can allocate resources to each process in some order and still avoid deadlock
questions.option3: A state where all processes are blocked
questions.option4: A state where no resources are available

questions.question: What is 'segmentation fault'?
questions.option1: An error in the disk controller
questions.option2: An attempt to access a memory location that a program is not allowed to access

questions.question: Which of the following is true about kernel-level threads?
questions.option1: They are managed by the user-level thread library.
questions.option2: The operating system is unaware of them.
questions.option3: They are directly supported and managed by the operating system kernel.
questions.option4: They offer faster context switching than user-level threads.

questions.question: What is the purpose of 'bootstrapping' in an operating system?
questions.option2: To load the operating system into memory when the computer starts

questions.question: What is the purpose of a 'super-block' in a file system?
questions.option1: To store data blocks of large files
questions.option2: To contain metadata about the file system itself (e.g., total blocks, free blocks)
questions.option3: To keep track of user permissions

questions.question: Which type of I/O operation causes the CPU to wait until the operation completes?
questions.option2: Non-blocking I/O

questions.question: What is a 'Trap' in operating systems?
questions.option2: A software-generated interrupt caused by an error or a specific request from a user program

questions.question: What is the primary function of the 'scheduler' in an operating system?
questions.option2: To select which process should run next on the CPU

questions.question: What is the 'Aging' technique used for in CPU scheduling?
questions.option1: To increase the priority of processes that have been waiting for a long time
questions.option2: To decrease the priority of long-running processes
questions.option3: To allocate more memory to older processes
questions.option4: To terminate processes that have been running too long

questions.question: Which of the following is a common method for inter-process communication (IPC)?
questions.option2: Paging

questions.question: What is the primary goal of the 'C-SCAN' disk scheduling algorithm?
questions.option1: To minimize head movement for individual requests
questions.option2: To provide more uniform wait times by scanning in one direction only, then resetting
questions.option4: To process requests in the order they arrive

questions.question: What is the difference between a 'virus' and a 'worm'?
questions.option1: Viruses do not self-replicate, worms do.
questions.option2: Worms require a host program to spread, viruses do not.
questions.option3: Viruses require a host program to spread, worms do not.
questions.option4: Viruses only affect executable files, worms affect all file types.

questions.question: What is 'System Protection' in operating systems primarily concerned with?
questions.option2: Ensuring proper access to system resources and preventing unauthorized access/malicious activity
questions.option3: Protecting user data from accidental deletion

questions.question: What is the purpose of 'memory-mapped files'?
questions.option2: To treat a file on disk as if it were part of a process's virtual memory space
questions.option3: To create temporary files in RAM

questions.question: What is 'booting' a computer?
questions.option2: The process of starting a computer and loading the operating system

questions.question: Which command is used to display the current working directory in Unix-like systems?
questions.option2: cd

questions.question: What is a 'filesystem block size'?
questions.option1: The size of a logical page in memory
questions.option2: The smallest unit of disk space that can be allocated to a file
questions.option3: The maximum size of a file
questions.option4: The amount of data transferred in a single I/O operation

questions.question: What is the significance of the 'Interrupt Vector' in an operating system?
questions.option2: It contains the addresses of all interrupt service routines.
questions.option3: It is used for CPU scheduling.

questions.question: What is a 'socket' in network programming?
questions.option1: A type of physical network connector
questions.option2: An endpoint for communication between two programs across a network
questions.option4: A device driver for network cards

questions.question: Which system call is used to terminate a process in Unix-like systems?
questions.option2: wait()

questions.question: What is the main advantage of 'virtual machines'?
questions.option1: They run directly on hardware, without an OS.
questions.option2: They allow multiple operating systems to run concurrently on a single physical machine.
questions.option3: They are only used for gaming.
questions.option4: They reduce the need for network connectivity.

questions.question: What is the role of a 'firmware'?
questions.option1: It is the main operating system.
questions.option2: It is software permanently stored in read-only memory (ROM), controlling hardware.
questions.option3: It is a type of application software.

questions.question: What does 'RAID 1' provide?
questions.option2: Mirroring (data duplication)

questions.question: What is the primary function of a 'Process Control Block (PCB)'?
questions.option1: To store the contents of a file
questions.option2: To store all the information about a process
questions.option4: To track memory usage of the entire system

questions.question: Which type of scheduler deals with moving processes between main memory and disk?
questions.option2: Medium-term scheduler

questions.question: What is the concept of 'portability' in operating systems?
questions.option1: The ability to run the OS on multiple types of hardware architectures.
questions.option2: The ability to easily transfer files between computers.
questions.option3: The ability to connect to different network types.
questions.option4: The ability to upgrade the OS without reinstalling.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of 'buffering' in I/O operations?
questions.option2: To improve efficiency by temporarily storing data during transfer.
